TITLE: Basic MailMimeParser Usage (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: This PHP snippet demonstrates fundamental usage of the MailMimeParser to parse an email message. It shows two primary methods: using a MailMimeParser instance to parse from a resource handle (like a file opened with fopen) or PSR-7 stream, and using the static Message::from() method to parse directly from a string. The example then illustrates how to retrieve common header values (Subject, From, To, CC) and access message content, including text parts and attachments. Dependencies include the zbateson/mail-mime-parser library and optionally guzzlehttp/psr7 for stream manipulation. Inputs are typically a string containing the email content or a resource/stream pointing to it. Outputs are scalar values, header objects, or content streams/strings.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/README.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
use ZBateson\MailMimeParser\MailMimeParser;
use ZBateson\MailMimeParser\Message;
use ZBateson\MailMimeParser\Header\HeaderConsts;

// use an instance of MailMimeParser as a class dependency
$mailParser = new MailMimeParser();

// parse() accepts a string, resource or Psr7 StreamInterface
// pass `true` as the second argument to attach the passed $handle and close
// it when the returned IMessage is destroyed.
$handle = fopen('file.mime', 'r');
$message = $mailParser->parse($handle, false);         // returns `IMessage`

// OR: use this procedurally (Message::from also accepts a string,
// resource or Psr7 StreamInterface
// true or false as second parameter doesn't matter if passing a string.
$string = "Content-Type: text/plain\r\nSubject: Test\r\n\r\nMessage";
$message = Message::from($string, false);

echo $message->getHeaderValue(HeaderConsts::FROM);     // user@example.com
echo $message
    ->getHeader(HeaderConsts::FROM)                    // AddressHeader
    ->getPersonName();                                 // Person Name
echo $message->getSubject();                           // The email's subject
echo $message
    ->getHeader(HeaderConsts::TO)                      // also AddressHeader
    ->getAddresses()[0]                                // AddressPart
    ->getPersonName();                                 // Person Name
echo $message
    ->getHeader(HeaderConsts::CC)                      // also AddressHeader
    ->getAddresses()[0]                                // AddressPart
    ->getEmail();                                      // user@example.com

echo $message->getTextContent();                       // or getHtmlContent()

echo $message->getHeader('X-Foo');                     // for custom or undocumented headers

$att = $message->getAttachmentPart(0);                 // first attachment
echo $att->getHeaderValue(HeaderConsts::CONTENT_TYPE); // e.g. "text/plain"
echo $att->getHeaderParameter(                         // value of "charset" part
    'content-type',
    'charset'
);
echo $att->getContent();                               // get the attached file's contents
$stream = $att->getContentStream();                    // the file is decoded automatically
$dest = \GuzzleHttp\Psr7\stream_for(
    fopen('my-file.ext')
);
\GuzzleHttp\Psr7\copy_to_stream(
    $stream, $dest
);
// OR: more simply if saving or copying to another stream
$att->saveContent('my-file.ext');               // writes to my-file.ext
$att->saveContent($stream);                     // copies to the stream

// close only when $message is no longer being used.
fclose($handle);

```

TITLE: Installing MailMimeParser via Composer (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: This command uses Composer, the PHP dependency manager, to add the zbateson/mail-mime-parser library to your project. Execute this command in the root directory of your PHP project where the composer.json file is located. Composer will download the library and its dependencies and update the autoloader.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/README.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
composer require zbateson/mail-mime-parser
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Handling MIME Multi-part messages in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates processing multipart MIME messages, including extracting individual parts such as plain text and HTML, handling content types, and decoding each part as necessary. It utilizes the 'email' library for parsing multipart messages and managing content boundaries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m1010.txt#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
from email import message_from_string

raw_email = '''
(MIME message with multiple parts)
'''
msg = message_from_string(raw_email)
for part in msg.walk():
    if part.get_content_type() == 'text/plain':
        print(part.get_payload(decode=True).decode('utf-8'))
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Base64 Decoding Function in JavaScript for MIME Content
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides a JavaScript function to decode base64-encoded strings, which are commonly used in email MIME parts to encode binary data such as images and attachments. Dependencies include built-in atob function or a polyfill to handle base64 decoding. The function takes an encoded string and returns decoded binary data, necessary for extracting and saving attachments or images from email messages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m2008.txt#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
function decodeBase64(encodedStr) {
    return atob(encodedStr);
}
```

TITLE: Parsing email headers in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the extraction and processing of email headers such as Message-ID, Date, From, To, and Subject from raw email data. It handles reading headers for email messages to facilitate further parsing and analysis.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m1010.txt#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
Message-ID: <392363E1.2AC47AB3@example.com>
Date: Wed, 17 May 2000 23:30:41 -0400
From: Doug Sauder <dwsauder@example.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.7 [en] (WinNT; I)
X-Accept-Language: en

Subject: Test message from Netscape Communicator 4.7
X-Priority: 5 (Lowest)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8

```

TITLE: Parsing MIME email headers in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to parse MIME email headers using Python's email library, extracting key header fields such as Subject, From, To, and Date. It requires the 'email' module and is essential for processing email metadata for applications like email clients or mail servers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m0001.txt#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
import email
import re

# Example raw email header
raw_headers = '''
From: "Doug Sauder" <doug@example.com>
To: "J�rgen Schm�rgen" <schmuergen@example.com>
Subject: Die Hasen und
Date: Wed, 17 May 2000 19:08:29 -0400
''' 

# Parse headers from raw string
headers = email.message_from_string(raw_headers)

# Extract specific header fields
subject = headers.get('Subject')
sender = headers.get('From')
date = headers.get('Date')

print(f"Subject: {subject}")
print(f"From: {sender}")
print(f"Date: {date}")
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing Multipart/Mixed Email Message with Boundary Handling
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to parse a multipart/mixed email message by splitting content using boundary markers specified in the Content-Type header. It processes nested multipart sections, such as related content or inline images, identifying different parts like text, images, and attachments. Dependencies include string manipulation and pattern matching, with key functionality being extraction of individual MIME parts for further processing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m2008.txt#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
function parseMultipartMessage(message, boundary) {
    const parts = message.split('--' + boundary);
    // process each part separately
    return parts.filter(part => part.trim() !== '');
}
```

TITLE: Decoding MIME-Encoded Email Headers in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides a function to decode MIME encoded email headers, such as subject lines with special characters. It relies on specific decoding functions to convert encoded words to readable text, supporting multiple character sets and encoding schemes. Necessary dependencies include MIME header decoding utilities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m0006.txt#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
function decodeMimeHeader(header) {\n    // Use a decoding library or custom decoder for MIME headers\n    const decoded = mimeDecode(header); // hypothetical function\n    return decoded;\n}
```

TITLE: Decoding quoted-printable email content in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides functionality to decode quoted-printable encoded email body content, which is essential for correctly rendering email messages with special characters and line breaks. It requires the 'quopri' library and handles decoding IRC, helping improve email readability.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m1010.txt#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
import quopri

def decode_quoted_printable(encoded_content):
    return quopri.decodestring(encoded_content).decode('utf-8')

email_body = "Die Hasen und die Fr=F6sche\n...\n"  # Encoded content
decoded_body = decode_quoted_printable(email_body)
print(decoded_body)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Decoding MIME message body in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to decode MIME message bodies using Python's email library, handling different content transfer encodings (like 8bit or base64). It reads raw email content, detects the content type and encoding, and decodes it for further processing, suitable for applications that need to display or analyze email content.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m0001.txt#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
import email
from email import policy

# Example raw email message
raw_message = '''
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Die Hasen und die Fr�sche
'''

# Parse the message from string
message = email.message_from_string(raw_message, policy=policy.default)

# Get payload, decode if necessary
if message.is_multipart():
    for part in message.walk():
        if part.get_content_type() == 'text/plain':
            payload = part.get_payload(decode=True)
            charset = part.get_content_charset()
            text = payload.decode(charset)
            print(text)
else:
    payload = message.get_payload(decode=True)
    charset = message.get_content_charset()
    text = payload.decode(charset)
    print(text)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Extracting and Decoding Quoted-Printable MIME Content in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet decodes MIME message bodies encoded in quoted-printable format, converting it into plain text. It requires a quoted-printable decoder utility, and is essential for processing email content with special characters or line breaks. Inputs include the encoded MIME body; outputs are the decoded text.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m0006.txt#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
function decodeQuotedPrintable(encodedText) {\n    // Utilize a quoted-printable decoding library or custom function\n    const decoded = quotedPrintableDecode(encodedText); // hypothetical function\n    return decoded;\n}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Extracting Content-Type and Content-Transfer-Encoding Headers
DESCRIPTION: This snippet extracts relevant headers like Content-Type and Content-Transfer-Encoding from MIME parts to determine how to decode the content. It involves regex or string matching to identify header values, which is essential in correctly decoding and rendering email content such as plain text or images. Dependencies include string processing functions, with key parameters being header names and their associated values.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m2008.txt#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
function extractHeaders(headersString) {
    const headers = {};
    headersString.split('\n').forEach(line => {
        const match = line.match(/^([^:]+):\s*(.+)$/);
        if (match) {
            headers[match[1].toLowerCase()] = match[2];
        }
    });
    return headers;
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing MIME Content Types and Boundaries in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet extracts MIME content type and boundary information from email headers to facilitate multipart message parsing. It scans header strings for parameters like 'Content-Type' and 'boundary', crucial for segmenting MIME parts. Dependencies include string processing utilities or regular expressions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m0006.txt#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
function parseMimeContentType(headers) {\n    const contentTypeMatch = headers.match(/Content-Type: ([^;]+);?\s*(boundary=([^;\s]+))?/i);\n    if (contentTypeMatch) {\n        return {\n            type: contentTypeMatch[1],\n            boundary: contentTypeMatch[3] || null\n        };\n    }\n    return null;\n}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Processing and Displaying Inline Images from MIME Data
DESCRIPTION: This snippet handles inline images embedded within email MIME parts, decoding base64 data, and assigning it to image elements with specific content IDs. It involves selecting image tags by Content-ID, decoding image data, and rendering inline images in an email client or viewer. Dependencies include DOM manipulation and base64 decoding; inputs include base64 image data and Content-ID references.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zbateson/mail-mime-parser/blob/master/tests/_data/emails/m2008.txt#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
function displayInlineImage(contentID, base64Data) {
    const img = document.querySelector(`img[src='cid:${contentID}']`);
    if (img) {
        img.src = 'data:image/png;base64,' + base64Data;
    }
}
```

TITLE: Defining MIME Headers and Multipart Boundary in Email Message MIME
DESCRIPTION: Defines the standard email header fields such as From, To, Subject, Date, Message-ID, and MIME version. It specifies the Content-Type as multipart/alternative and declares a unique boundary string used to separate different parts of the email body. This snippet is critical for email clients to correctly interpret and render the message parts. Dependencies include compliance to MIME RFC standards. Key parameters include the headers that identify message metadata and the boundary string used to parse multipart content. Inputs are raw header lines; output is a correctly formatted email header section.

CODE:

```
The Hare and the Tortoise=20
=20
A HARE one day ridiculed the short feet and slow pace of the Tortoise, =
who replied, laughing:  "Though you be swift as the wind, I will beat =
you in a race."  The Hare, believing her assertion to be simply =
impossible, assented to the proposal; and they agreed that the Fox =
should choose the course and fix the goal.  On the day appointed for the =
race the two started together.  The Tortoise never for a moment stopped, =
but went on with a slow but steady pace straight to the end of the =
course.  The Hare, lying down by the wayside, fell fast asleep.  At last =
waking up, and moving as fast as he could, he saw the Tortoise had =
reached the goal, and was comfortably dozing after her fatigue. =20
=20
Slow but steady wins the race. =20

```

DESCRIPTION: The HTML portion of a multipart email that includes text content with German characters and references to inline images using Content-ID. The HTML is structured with basic formatting tags for paragraph breaks and styling.

```
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<img SRC="cid:part1.39235FC5.E71D8178@example.com" ALT="blue ball" height=27 width=27><b></b>
<p><b>Die Hasen und die Frösche</b>
<p>Die Hasen klagten einst über ihre mißliche Lage; "wir leben",
sprach ein Redner, "in steter Furcht vor Menschen und Tieren, eine Beute
der Hunde, der Adler, ja fast aller Raubtiere! Unsere stete Angst ist ärger
als der Tod selbst. Auf, laßt uns ein für allemal sterben."
<p>In einem nahen Teich wollten sie sich nun ersäufen; sie eilten
ihm zu; allein das außerordentliche Getöse und ihre wunderbare
Gestalt erschreckte eine Menge Frösche, die am Ufer saßen, so
sehr, daß sie aufs schnellste untertauchten.
<p>"Halt", rief nun eben dieser Sprecher, "wir wollen das Ersäufen
noch ein wenig aufschieben, denn auch uns fürchten, wie ihr seht,
einige Tiere, welche also wohl noch unglücklicher sein müssen
als wir."
<p><img SRC="cid:part2.39235FC5.E71D8178@example.com" height=27 width=27>
<br> 
<br> </html>
```

```
The Hare and the Tortoise 
 
A HARE one day ridiculed the short feet and slow pace of the Tortoise,
who replied, laughing:  "Though you be swift as the wind, I will beat
you in a race."  The Hare, believing her assertion to be simply
impossible, assented to the proposal; and they agreed that the Fox
should choose the course and fix the goal.  On the day appointed for the
race the two started together.  The Tortoise never for a moment stopped,
but went on with a slow but steady pace straight to the end of the
course.  The Hare, lying down by the wayside, fell fast asleep.  At last
waking up, and moving as fast as he could, he saw the Tortoise had
reached the goal, and was comfortably dozing after her fatigue.  
 
Slow but steady wins the race.
```

```
der Adler, ja fast aller Raubtiere! Unsere stete Angst ist +PGc-er als der
Tod selbst. Auf, la+B7Q- uns ein f+vCA-allemal sterben." 

In einem nahen Teich wollten sie sich nun ers+PSY-en; sie eilten ihm zu;
allein das au+B6U-rordentliche Get+XKU- und ihre wunderbare Gestalt
erschreckte eine Menge Fr+XKM-he, die am Ufer sa+B6U-n, so sehr, da+B2A-sie aufs
schnellste untertauchten. 

"Halt", rief nun eben dieser Sprecher, "wir wollen das Ers+PSY-en noch ein
wenig aufschieben, denn auch uns f+vGM-hten, wie ihr seht, einige Tiere,
welche also wohl noch ungl+uKs-licher sein m+vLM-en als wir."
```
